titleStmt.title: Some account of the great sea-fight, wherein Their Majesties navy-royal, in conjunction with the Dutch squadron, engaged the French fleet off of Cape Barfleur, on the nineteenth of May, 1692. : And put them to flight, burning and sinking many of their ships so that the sea appeared full of wrecks of ships for two leagues together. : With an account of the sinking the French admiral, and his two seconds: : running many of their ships a-ground, which are destroyed by our fleet. : And some other particulars relating to this glorious success and victory over the common enemy. : Licensed according to order.

titleStmt.title: Some account of the great sea-fight, wherein Their Majesties navy-royal, in conjunction with the Dutch squadron, engaged the French fleet off of Cape Barfleur, on the nineteenth of May, 1692. : And put them to flight, burning and sinking many of their ships so that the sea appeared full of wrecks of ships for two leagues together. : With an account of the sinking the French admiral, and his two seconds: : running many of their ships a-ground, which are destroyed by our fleet. : And some other particulars relating to this glorious success and victory over the common enemy. : Licensed according to order.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: Some ACCOUNT of the Great Sea-Fight, Wherein Their MAJESTIES NAVY-ROYAL, In Conjunction with the Dutch Squadron, ENGAGED THE French Fleet Off of CAPE BARFLEVR, On the Nineteenth of May, 1692.
AND Put them to Flight, Burning and Sinking many of their Ships, Å¿o that the Sea appeared full of Wrecks of Ships for Two Leagues together.
WITH AN Account of the Sinking the French Admiral, and his two Seconds: Running many of their Ships a-ground, which are deÅ¿troyed by our Fleet.
AND Some other Particulars relating to this glorious SucceÅ¿s and Victory over the Common Enemy.
LONDON, Printed for P. Brooksby, J. Deacon, J. Blare, and J. Back. 1692.

div.head: Some ACCOUNT of the Great Sea-Fight, Wherein Their MAJESTIES NAVY-ROYAL, In Conjunction with the Dutch Squadron, Engaged the French Fleet, &c.
div.p:
THE French thinking to do great Matters at Sea this Summer, got their Fleet out Å¿omewhat Å¿ooner than than they were wont, appearing more numerous and daring than they did the laÅ¿t Summer; Å¿o that on the 9th. of May, their whole Fleet, conÅ¿iÅ¿ting of about 100 Sail, was, about Noon, Å¿een off of Dartmouth, at a great DiÅ¿tance, viz. three Leagues from the Start, and continued turning to the EaÅ¿tward, the Wind at EaÅ¿t and by North; and the next Day,
they were again Å¿een from the Å¿ame Place, when, by their Å¿ailing, they Å¿eemed as if they intended to Å¿tand to their own CoaÅ¿t: And our Fleet being now well mann'd, and in a very good ReadineÅ¿s, on the 14th. of May, in the Afternoon, Admiral RuÅ¿Å¿el weighed Anchor out of Rye Bay, and about eleven the next Morning joyned Sir Ralph Delaval, and Rear-Admiral Carter at St. Helens, and Å¿oon after divers Dutch Men of War came to joyn him, Å¿o that the whole Fleet conÅ¿iÅ¿ted of about Ninety Sail of Ships for the Line of Battel, the Officers and Seamen being very hearty and full of Courage, and every thing gave a happy PreÅ¿age of the Glorious SucceÅ¿s that Å¿oon after enÅ¿ued, as appears by the Loyal AddreÅ¿s, humbly preÅ¿ented to Her MajeÅ¿ty by the Chief Commanders of her Fleet; which for the Satisfaction of the Reader, it may not be amiÅ¿s to Incert, as an Introduction to Å¿o glorious an Enterprize, viz.

The Queen being informed of a Å¿candalous and malitious Report that was Å¿pread abroad, as if Å¿ome of the Officers of their MajeÅ¿ties Fleet were diÅ¿affected, or not hearty in their Service, and that her MajeÅ¿ty had thereupon ordered the DiÅ¿charge of many of them from their Employments; Her MajeÅ¿ty was pleaÅ¿ed to command the Earl of Nottingham to write to Admiral RuÅ¿Å¿el, and let him know, that her Her MajeÅ¿ty was Å¿atisfied that this Report was raiÅ¿ed by the Enemies of the Government, and that Å¿he repoÅ¿ed Å¿o entire a Confidence in their Fidelity, that Å¿he had reÅ¿olved not to diÅ¿place any one of them; which being by the Admiral communicated to them, they made and Å¿ent up the following AddreÅ¿s.

p.q:
WE Your MajeÅ¿ty's moÅ¿t dutiful and loyal Subjects and Servants, Flag-Officers and Captains in Your MajeÅ¿ty's Fleet; out of the deep and grateful SenÅ¿e we have of Your MajeÅ¿ty's good and juÅ¿t Opinion of our Loyalty and Fidelity Imparted to us by the Right Honourable Admiral RuÅ¿Å¿el, in a Letter to him from my Lord Nottingham, do, in the behalf of our Å¿elves, and all other Officers and Seamen, preÅ¿ume to addreÅ¿s our Å¿elves to your MajeÅ¿ty at this Juncture, to undeceive
the World in thoÅ¿e falÅ¿e and malitious Reports that have been lately Å¿pread in prejudice of Your MajeÅ¿ty's Service, by People of an unreaÅ¿onable DiÅ¿affection to Your MajeÅ¿ty's Government, and an obÅ¿tinate AverÅ¿ion to the Quiet and Good of our Country, that there are Å¿ome amongÅ¿t us that are not truly zealous for, and entirely devoted to your MajeÅ¿ty's Service; we do therefore moÅ¿t humbly beg Your MajeÅ¿ty's Leave to add to our repeated Oaths, this AÅ¿Å¿urance of our Fidelity, that we with all imaginable Alacrity and ReÅ¿olution, venture our Lives in the Defence of Your MajeÅ¿ty's undoubted Rights, and the Liberty and Religion of our Country, againÅ¿t all Foreign and PopiÅ¿h Invaders whatÅ¿oever; and that God Almighty may preÅ¿erve Your MajeÅ¿ty's moÅ¿t Å¿acred PerÅ¿on, direct your Councils, and proÅ¿per Your Arms by Sea and Land againÅ¿t Your MajeÅ¿ty's Enemies, Let all the People Å¿ay Amen, with Your MajeÅ¿ty's Dutiful and Loyal Subjects.

closer.dateline: Dated on Board the Britannia, at St. Helens. May, 15. 1691.

div.p: This was Å¿igned by Sir John AÅ¿hby, Admiral of the Blew, Sir Ralph Delaval, Vice Admiral of the Red, Mr. Rook, Vice Admiral of the Blew, Sir ClouÅ¿ly Shouel, Rear Admiral of the Red, Mr. Carter, Rear Admiral of the Blew; upon receiving which, her MajeÅ¿ty was pleaÅ¿ed to Å¿ay, That Å¿he had always this Opinion of the Commanders, but was glad this was come to Å¿atisfie others.

The EngliÅ¿h and Dutch Fleets having now taken the Seas, on the 18th. of May, the Admirals Scouts, whilÅ¿t he bore South WeÅ¿t and by South, Å¿even Leagues from Cape Barfleur, made the Signal for Å¿eeing the Enemy, the Wind WeÅ¿twardly: The French bore down upon our Fleet, and about eleven engaged it, but at Å¿ome diÅ¿tance; we continued fighting till half an hour paÅ¿t five in the Evening, at which time, the Enemy towed away with all their Boats, and we after them. It was calm all day, about Å¿ix there was a freÅ¿h Engagement to the WeÅ¿tward
of the Admiral, Å¿uppoÅ¿ed to be the Blew, and it continued calm all Night, but the Particulars at preÅ¿ent, are only, that the French were beaten, and the Admiral was Å¿teering away for Conquet Road, having a freÅ¿h Gale EaÅ¿terly (but very foggy) that being the place he Å¿uppoÅ¿ed they deÅ¿igned for; and that if it pleaÅ¿ed God to Å¿end Fair Weather, he doubted not but to deÅ¿troy the whole French Fleet. In the Night, three or four Ships were Å¿een to blow up, but not known what they were.

As to Å¿ome other Particulars, it appears by another Advice, That about the grey or opening of the Morning, our Fleet made the French Fleet in a Line of Battel, about two Leagues to the Windward; and they then having the Weather-gage, bore down very boldly and cloÅ¿ely upon our Fleet; at Eleven the Engagement began, and continued very hot and furious till almoÅ¿t four in the Afternoon, at what time the French Fleet bore away. The Wind at WeÅ¿t by South, and WeÅ¿t South WeÅ¿t, veering about to North by EaÅ¿t, and North North EaÅ¿t, Sir ClouÅ¿ly Shouel, and Sir John AÅ¿hby, having the Weathergage, fell bravely on, maintaining the Engagement till almoÅ¿t ten at Night; the French all that while bearing away, and the EngliÅ¿h purÅ¿uing them, Å¿ome Ships were Å¿een in the Nighttime in flames, about nine of the Clock; but not knowing what they were, nor likewiÅ¿e the damage Å¿uÅ¿tained on either Å¿ide, when this Advice came away.

But Å¿ince this, the Mary Galley came from Admiral RuÅ¿Å¿el, to Spithead; who left him at Eight in the morning, about fifteen Leagues South and by WeÅ¿t from the IÅ¿le of Wight, declaring he Å¿aw both the French Admirals Seconds Å¿unk, and many Ships on fire, and that for the Å¿pace of two Leagues together the Sea was full of Wrecks of Ships, but knew not of the loÅ¿s of any of their MajeÅ¿ties Ships or Commanders; and that when this Galley came away, the French were running, and the EngliÅ¿h in purÅ¿uit of them; and about Ten of the Clock he heard them Engag'd again, and the Guns firing till One, at what time the Wind Å¿prung up at South and by WeÅ¿t.

Upon this News, and ever to be wiÅ¿h'd-for SucceÅ¿s, as well by Land as Sea, of which Heaven has given us already Å¿o great an EarneÅ¿t of future Improvement againÅ¿t the Common Enemy, not only the Joy of all good Subjects abounded, but the Bells, in all places where it came, were rung out; the Tower-Guns, and thoÅ¿e in other places, were diÅ¿charged, and the Streets, at Night, filled with Bonfires and Illuminations, to the great contentment and rejoycing of the Nation.

Since the former Advices, a Letter came from PortÅ¿mouth, bearing date the 21Å¿t. of May, giving an Account that Their MajeÅ¿ties Ship the Montague, Captain Foulk Commander, came in thither from the Fleet, his Ship being diÅ¿abled in the Fight, he leaving the Fleet the day before, about Nine of the Clock in the morning, purÅ¿uing the Enemy; and Å¿ays, that Mr. Carter, Reer-Admiral of the Blue, was kill'd in the Action. And the Å¿ame Letter further relates, That Captain KillingÅ¿worth, Commander of the Fox Fire-Å¿hip, had made his way to PortÅ¿mouth in his Boat; and gave an Account, That he had burnt his FireÅ¿hip on board the French Reer-Admiral, but was put off with a great deal of difficulty; and that he Å¿aw a French Man-of-War, of about Seventy Guns, blow up, and another Three-deck'd Ship on fire.

On the Twenty firÅ¿t, about Nine of the Clock in the morning, our Fleet Å¿et Å¿ail again; as likewiÅ¿e did the French: Admiral RuÅ¿Å¿el took his courÅ¿e towards Barfleur, having got Å¿ight of divers Ships under the Å¿hore: Admiral Allemond, of the Dutch, and the Admiral of the Blue, Å¿ailed to the WeÅ¿tward. The firÅ¿t of theÅ¿e endeavoured to get up with Å¿ixteen of the Enemies Ships which he diÅ¿covered, Å¿uppoÅ¿ing them to be coming from France to joyn the French Fleet. Sir John AÅ¿hby purÅ¿ued the reÅ¿t of the French Fleet, who in much ConfuÅ¿ion laboured to get into the Rafe of Ornay. Admiral Allemond loÅ¿t Å¿ight of the afore-mentioned Å¿ixteen Ships in the night, they having, as he Å¿uppoÅ¿ed, got in among the Rocks; and becauÅ¿e he found it not Å¿afe nor convenient to follow them there, he Å¿ailed EaÅ¿tward again, to rejoyn Admiral RuÅ¿Å¿el.

On the Twenty Å¿econd, in the Morning, Vice-Admiral Delaval burnt, near to the Å¿hore, under Cape de Wike, a great Ship, called the Royal Sun, of France, being the Ship of Count de Tourville, the French Admiral, carrying a Hundred and Four Guns; as likewiÅ¿e the Admiral commanded by his Second, MonÅ¿ieur Beaujeu, a Ship carrying a Hundred and two Guns; and the Fort of Eighty Guns; with two Frigats, and Three of leÅ¿Å¿er rank: And Admiral RuÅ¿Å¿el was in cloÅ¿e purÅ¿uit of Nine more. The PriÅ¿oners who were taken from the burnt Ships, declared, That during the time of the Battel, 4 or 5 of their biggeÅ¿t Ships were deÅ¿troyed. Reer-Admiral Carter, and Collonel HaÅ¿tings, after much Bravery and ReÅ¿olution, were both killed in the Fight: And at this time an Account came from PortÅ¿mouth, that four French Ships, of three Decks, lay on the back of the IÅ¿le of Wight, extremely diÅ¿abled; and that two EngliÅ¿h Men of War, who were refitted, with two Dutch Frigates, and a Fire-Å¿hip, were going againÅ¿t them, to take or deÅ¿troy them.
